title: Study demonstrates vaccines' safety, lack of link to autism
description: New research finds no evidence that thimerosal-containing vaccines cause negative behaviors or result in neuropathology in infant primates, according to a study (PDF) published today in PNAS, the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
cleaned_text: News Archive Study demonstrates vaccines' safety, lack of link to autism New research finds no evidence that thimerosal-containing vaccines cause negative behaviors or result in neuropathology in infant primates, according to a [study (PDF)](/sites/default/files/sites/default/files/documents/PNAS-2015-Gadad-1500968112.pdf) published today in PNAS, the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. In the study, infant rhesus macaques received several pediatric vaccines containing thimerosal, a mercury-based preservative, in a schedule similar to that given to infants in the 1990s. Other animals received just the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine, which does not contain thimerosal, or an expanded vaccine schedule similar to that recommended for U.S. infants today. Control animals received a saline injection. Regardless of vaccination status, all animals developed normal social behaviors; the administration of vaccines to rhesus macaques did not result in neuropathological abnormalities or aberrant behaviors such as those often observed in autism. autism-puzzle Cellular analysis of the cerebellum, amygdala and hippocampus - three brain regions known to be altered in autism - was similar in vaccinated and unvaccinated animals. "This comprehensive study included many physiological measures and behavioral measures. Fundamentally the vaccines had no ill effects," said [Gene Sackett](http://depts.washington.edu/chdd/iddrc/res_aff/sackett.html), UW professor emeritus of psychology and director of the lab work at the Washington National Primate Research Center. "To the extent that macaques mirror human physiology, I think this bears out what most people have known: These vaccines are safe." [Laura Hewitson](http://www.johnson-center.org/index.php/site/staff/laura_hewitson) of The Johnson Center for Child Health and Development, a principle investigator, said the study was designed to compare the safety of different vaccination schedules, including the schedule from the 1990s, when thimerosal was used as a preservative in multidose vaccine preparations. The research also involved the UW's Center on Human Development and Disability; the University of Texas Southwestern; and Texas A&M Health Science Center & Central Texas Veterans Health Care System.
